title: Trainer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Compassion International (Colorado Springs, CO) in Oct 2022
Interview Descriptions: Compassion has a very extensive interview process for entry level jobs. I put in a lot of time and effort into this interview process, only for them to hire an internal candidate. I had 5 separate interviews. A phone screening, zoom with a panel, two interviews with the panel in person, and the last interview with the panel and actual manager. I was asked to prepare something and review it with the panel for my third interview. This task took me a lot of time/effort to prepare for. When I went to review it with the panel, I felt that they did not prepare me for presenting the task. I left feeling incompetent and embarrassed and not expecting to continue in the interview process. I was surprised to make the final interview. I was also asked the same questions in almost every interview, which made the process frustrating. The whole process took over two months from start to finish. Each interview was over a week apart. After the last interview, it took them almost two weeks to let me know whether I had gotten the job. The process took way longer than I had anticipated or would expect in the interview process (again, for an entry level position). I think once you get hired, this company is amazing, but they are not super up front about how extensive the interview process can be. They should also be more up front about internal candidates. I would have left this interview process had I known the full scope of the situation. I have heard similar stories from multiple people who have interviewed with Compassion. I will not be applying to this company again.
Interview Questions: What previous experience will you bring into this position?

title: Senior Software Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at Compassion International (Colorado Springs, CO) in Nov 2018
Interview Descriptions:
I applied online and was contacted within 2 weeks. My first interview was over HireVue where I recorded my response to about 4 questions. They included questions like “what is a recent project you worked on and go into as much detail as you can about each layer,” “describe your contributions to any open source projects,” and “what is your experience with Agile.” The second interview was through CodeView with 2 programming questions with the first being 20 minutes and the second being 40 minutes – you can choose what language you write. The next round of interviews was with an IT manager over Zoom where I was asked technical questions like “what are some of the big things going on in the tech industry right now,” “describe full stack development,” and some other questions about my development experience and specific projects on my resume – overall it felt pretty casual which was nice. Next interview was through Zoom with about 3 people from the development team where I was asked more specific questions about object oriented design, the software development lifecycle, my experience with version control, how I handled conflict in projects before, etc. The last interview was with 3 managers where they asked me what kinds of things I wanted/did not want to work on, and some questions from previous interviews. Of course, you get a lot of opportunity to ask questions along the way.

Overall, Compassion is a great company to interview with and work for!
Interview Questions: (40 minutes) Return the number of primes in a given interval. For example, given string “[1,6]” you should return 3

title: Strategic Business Partner Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Compassion International (Colorado Springs, CO) in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions: Over the last few years I have applied for a couple of different positions.  The first position I never heard anything from them, the only way I knew they were no longer interested was by checking their website and finding the application had moved from open to closed (which that in and of itself took 3-4 months).  The second time it was a similar experience.  Then after they closed my second application they called me and asked if I would be interested in a similar position.  We discussed the position and found it aligned almost identically with what I was currently doing.  They had me fly to their office and meet with the various people in the department and with people this position interacted with outside of their department.  The people were very nice and it was a very encouraging experience.  This disappointment came in when at the end of the day I was finishing up with the executive recruiter and he was discussing next steps, I asked him what the timing would be in hearing back from them.  He said "You are exactly what we are looking for, if I have may way you will have the job and we should be able to get in touch with you by the end of the week, possibly the beginning of the following week."  Well I didn't hear back from them for more than two weeks and it was by email.  My belief is if you fly to an organization for a face to face interview, you should be given the courtesy of a verbal conversation when not selected.  I ended up calling them to understand better what happened since I was told I was basically an ideal candidate.  It was a good conversation and I don't have any hard feelings, but it was a bit confusing and I felt I got several mixed messages.
Interview Questions: Why are you looking to work for us?

title: ISDS Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Compassion International (Colorado Springs, CO) in Apr 2009
Interview Descriptions:
Compassion's hiring and interview process, at least for me, was very smooth and hassle-free. As with most jobs, networking certainly helps: Compassion receives thousands of applications a month as it is one of the most desirable Christian ministries to work for in the world. I recall about a two-week window from when I applied to when I was hired, but this is not typical -- most applicants wait at least three months to receive an initial phone call if they're being considered.

The interview itself was calm and enjoyable overall -- my position was basically entry level and the interview questions were therefore what you would expect: "Tell us about a time when you had a conflict and how you resolved it," "What are your strengths and weakness?" "Where do you see yourself in five years?" etc. Their favorite questions seems to be "What are you passionate about?"

After the interview, which was probably about 45 minutes, they got back to me the next day and offered me the job. Again, an atypically fast hiring process from start to finish, and I enjoyed it.
Interview Questions: "What are you passionate about?" Make sure your answer is substantial and meaningful. For example, don't put all your chips on the fact that you're passionate about Ultimate Frisbee.
